results.title: MLK/FBI
results.creator_credit: Dedalus Wainwright, Sheila Griffin, Benjamin Hedin, Kate Hurwitz, Brian Becker, Laura Tomaselli, Sam Pollard, IFC Films and Field of Vision
results.brief_description: Based on newly declassified files, the film explores the US government’s surveillance and harassment of Martin Luther King, Jr.

constellations_primary.name: MLK/FBI: blackness In America
constellations_primary.description: Award-winning documentarian Sam Pollard looks at J. Edgar Hoover and the FBI’s pursuit of Martin Luther King Jr in the lead-up to his assassination during America’s Civil Rights Movement of the sixties.

results.title: Neon
results.creator_credit: Salik Silverstein, Alex Proyas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A single-frame time-lapse journey through Sydney, the surrealistic city. Figures dart in and out of the shadows of the night. A kaleidoscope of imagery flies by - incorporates people in subways, cars on freeways, city streets and buildings. The music (by Fad Gadget) drives the images to a tumultuous climax.

results.title: The Repco-Brabham story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Production
results.brief_description: Briefly shows manufacture and testing of racing cars by the Brabham Racing Organisation in England, followed by views of the 1965 Tasman Series motor races in Australia and New Zealand, Jack Brabham and others competing in Brabham cars. Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

results.title: Endoscopic Vanitas (No Veins Version)
results.material_description: skull, endoscopic cameras, mechanised mount, transformer, fog machine and projection
results.brief_description:
“Endoscopic Vanitas (No Veins Version)” is a reworking of a past work, originally exhibited in 2009 at the Venice Biennale, commissioned for the exhibition “Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences”.

In the centre of the room a single human skull hangs suspended by a metal frame. An endoscopic camera moves inside the skull, a second explores its exterior. The images captured by the two cameras are projected onto separate screens, the first a mist screen that sits at the entrance to the room creating a permeable barrier to the cavernous space behind, the second a simple LCD screen inside the room. These images appear abstract, suggestive, lunar. Gladwell is playing with the time-honoured trope of the momento mori, as well as with Plato’s ‘allegory of the cave’.

results.title: Touch wood: five Tasmanian woodworkers
results.brief_description: About five men who live in Tasmania and earn their living by working with wood. David Ralph makes small souvenir animals and furniture from horizontal wood; Kevin Perkins makes furniture which allows the natural shape of the wood to be shown; Merv Gray and Peter Mevre make bowls and spheres, and Peter Taylor sculptural pieces.

results.title: Nippers, chompers, grinders
results.creator_credit: Judy Nelson and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A film on dental hygiene for children ages 5-8. Janis, who refuses to brush her teeth, disappears down the plughole in order to escape that boring task. She meets three monsters, Nippers, Chompers and Grinders, each with specific tooth ailments and helps them overcome their disabilities. Voices: Valma Bolton, Colin Van Cao, Evelyn Krape, Stephen Radic, Claire Dobbin.

results.title: Frontline
results.creator_credit: David Bradbury, Australian War Memorial, Tasmanian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, British Broadcasting Corporation and ABC
results.brief_description:
An account of the Vietnam War as seen through the camera of the late Australian war correspondent, Neil Davis. David Bradbury’s multi-award winning documentary also examines the ethical issues facing a man in the frontline who is not an active combatant.
Vietnam was a television war, a war said to have been lost in the lounge rooms of middle America, and not on the battlefield. This film explores the conflict, and Davis’ involvement in it, combining his original footage, comments and archival film. It includes the famous, historic footage of the fall of Saigon, which Davis was the only Western journalist to film.
